articles.headline: Natural Gas Now Viewed as Safer Bet
articles.snippet: The calamitous events in Japan may roll back the global nuclear revival and lead to a surge in natural gas demand.
articles.abstract: The calamitous events in Japan may roll back the global nuclear revival and lead to a surge in natural gas demand.
articles.lead_paragraph: Natural gas may be having its day, as its rival energy sources come under a cloud.

articles.headline: A Panel Decides Washington State’s Health Care Costs
articles.snippet: The committee has authority to determine which medical devices and procedures the state will cover for its employees, Medicaid patients and injured workers.
articles.abstract: The committee has authority to determine which medical devices and procedures the state will cover for its employees, Medicaid patients and injured workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The health care board was in session, and Deryk Lamb was pleading for them to continue paying for the spinal injections he receives to dull the pain from a workplace injury.

articles.headline: Japanese Town Holds On to Hope
articles.snippet: In a town where more than one in 10 is dead or missing, people seem to exist in suspended animation.
articles.abstract: In a town where more than one in 10 is dead or missing, people seem to exist in suspended animation.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIKUZENTAKATA, Japan — On the afternoon of Friday, March 11, the Takata High School swim team walked a half-mile to practice at the city’s nearly new natatorium, overlooking the broad sand beach of Hirota Bay.

articles.headline: Unmarried Pastor, Seeking a Job, Sees Bias
articles.snippet: Among conservative Protestants, there is often a requirement — whether clearly stated or implicit — that the pastor be married, ideally with children.
articles.abstract: Among conservative Protestants, there is often a requirement — whether clearly stated or implicit — that the pastor be married, ideally with children.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like all too many Americans, Mark Almlie was laid off in the spring of 2009 when his workplace downsized. He has been searching for an appropriate position ever since, replying to more than 500 job postings without success.

articles.headline: Japan Extended Reactor’s Life, Despite Warning
articles.snippet: Regulators approved a 10-year extension for the oldest reactor at the Fukushima Daiichi plant despite safety warnings.
articles.abstract: Regulators approved a 10-year extension for the oldest reactor at the Fukushima Daiichi plant despite safety warnings.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Just a month before a powerful earthquake and tsunami crippled the Fukushima Daiichi plant at the center of Japan’s nuclear crisis, government regulators approved a 10-year extension for the oldest of the six reactors at the power station despite warnings about its safety.
articles.byline: By Hiroko Tabuchi, Norimitsu Onishi and Ken Belson

articles.headline: Sharp Scrutiny for Merger of AT&T and T-Mobile
articles.snippet: The two primary agencies that will oversee the merger view it with different goals in mind.
articles.abstract: The two primary agencies that will oversee the merger view it with different goals in mind.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Mega-mergers may be celebrated on Wall Street on the theory that bigger is better. But the proposed merger of AT&T and T-Mobile is likely to face intense scrutiny by regulators, lawmakers and consumer advocates.

articles.headline: For Consumers, Little to Cheer in AT&T Deal
articles.snippet: A merger with T-Mobile would leave just three major cellular carriers in the United States, which could lead to higher prices.
articles.abstract: A merger with T-Mobile would leave just three major cellular carriers in the United States, which could lead to higher prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: The $39 billion proposed merger of AT&T and T-Mobile could save the companies a lot of money. For everyone else, it could cost a lot of money. No sooner did the two companies announce a $39 billion merger on Sunday than industry analysts began assessing the impact on the biggest potential losers in the deal: consumers.

articles.headline: Obama Seeks to Unify Allies as More Airstrikes Rock Tripoli
articles.snippet: President Obama worked to bridge differences among allies about how to manage the campaign, and forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi showed no sign of ending their sieges of rebel-held cities.
articles.abstract: President Obama worked to bridge differences among allies about how to manage the campaign, and forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi showed no sign of ending their sieges of rebel-held cities.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama worked on Tuesday to bridge differences among allies about how to manage the military campaign in Libya, as airstrikes continued to rock Tripoli. Forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, however, showed no sign of ending their sieges of rebel-held cities.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Steven Erlanger
